dir-section.heading: The Roman Catholic Church
dir-section.p: The Roman Catholic Church was granted full legal status in May 1989, when legislation guaranteeing freedom of worship was approved. The Church was also permitted to administer its own affairs, and to operate schools, hospitals and other charitable organizations. A Concordat, agreed by the Polish Government and the Holy See in 1993, was ratified in January 1998.

For ecclesiastical purposes, Poland comprises 15 archdioceses (including one for the Catholics of the Byzantine-Ukrainian rite) and 28 dioceses (including one for the Catholics of the Byzantine-Ukrainian rite), an Ordinariate for the faithful of the Eastern rites, and a Military Ordinariate. At the time of the 2021 census, there were 27.1m. adherents in Poland (71.3% of the population).

dir-entry.dir-entry-name: Archbishop of Gniezno, Primate of Poland

org-entry.content-note: comprises six dioceses, six archbishoprics and three bishoprics

role-group.role: Metropolitan of Warsaw and All Poland

dir-section.heading: Protestant Churches

org-entry-head.org-entry-name: Evangelical Church of the Augsburg Confession in Poland

dir-section.p: There are also several other small Protestant churches, including the Church of Evangelical Christians, the Evangelical Reformed Church, the Jehovah’s Witnesses, the Pentecostal Church, the Seventh-day Adventist Church and the United Methodist Church.

dir-section.heading: Islam
dir-section.p: There are very few Muslims in Poland.

org-entry-head.org-entry-name: Religious Union of Muslims in Poland

dir-section.heading: Judaism
dir-section.p: Much of the Jewish population of Poland was killed during the occupation by Nazi Germany in the Second World War. In 2023 there were believed to be some 4,500 Jews in Poland.

org-entry-head.org-entry-name: Union of Jewish Communities in Poland
org-entry-head.alt-name: Związek Gmin Wyznaniowych Żydowskich w Rzeczypospolitej Polskiej
